intro: Craspedostoma linoides, commonly known as the threadleaf tamarisk, is a shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its small, linear leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white wax, which helps reduce water loss in hot, dry environments. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in dense clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It has a deep root system that allows it to access groundwater, making it well adapted to drought conditions. Craspedostoma linoides is often found in rocky soils and can thrive in both full sun and partial shade.
